title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:

  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Helvetica][SIZE=15px]PPBUS_G3H -   0.195v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Helvetica][SIZE=15px]PP3V42_G3H -  3.398v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Helvetica][SIZE=15px]PP5V_S5  - 0.00v    [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

Thanks[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: put black end of multimeter on pin 1 of c7050, put red end of multimeter on pin 2 of c7050, in resistance mode. what do you get?

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: C7050 - 6.74M Ohms

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: before i get to a real computer to provide proper answer, you tell me why that is very very wrong :) add resistance of r7050, r7051, and r7052.. do they add up to 2.203 ohms, or 6,740,000 ohms? :) go hunt for your break in the line!

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: So R7052 should be connected to R7050 thru that via?

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:
YES!
R7051, R752 and R7050 have to be physically connected!
These are responsible for current sense ....
According to your description your machine thinks it is on fire and shuts PPBUS off

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: Now go run a wire!

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: Thanks, like I said, my schematic does NOT show R7502 connected to U7000, that's why I wanted to ask and double check what it should be connected to. I'm not stupid, just careful.

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: R7052 came off the board when I was attempting to connect the jumper wire to Pin 2. Because it's a 0 ohm resistor, is it crazy of me to consider just connecting the jumper directly to the Pin 1 pad, thereby replacing the 0 ohm resistor with a 0 ohm jumper wire?

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:
[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px]OK, so I jumped R7050 Pin 2/4 to R7052 Pin 1 solder pad (R7052 is not on the board anymore, is that OK??)[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px][B]NOW have 12.5v on PPBUS_G3H and PP5V_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are now present too.[/B][/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]


[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Helvetica][SIZE=15px]But still no fan, [B]do[/B] still have Green LED and these voltages:

PPDCIN_G3H - 17.03v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Helvetica][SIZE=15px]PPBUS_G3H - 12.56v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Helvetica][SIZE=15px]PP3V42_G3H - 3.398v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Helvetica][SIZE=15px]PP5V_S5 - 4.99v [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Helvetica][SIZE=15px]PP3V3_S5 - 3.32v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]


[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Helvetica][SIZE=14px][COLOR=#000000]PP5V_S0[/COLOR] - 0.00v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

However, U7740 is a No Stuff on this logic board...:eek:

Thoughts?[/SIZE][/FONT]

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: Hello? Louis, Duke?

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:
PP1V05_S5 is not needed....
PM_SLP_S4_L is present?????
By the way, use a 0 ohm resistor for R7052 and the wire just for rebuild the trace....

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: Check PP5V_S3 for short first and then see if it pulses when power is applied. It may only pulse once very shortly after connecting power so check carefully.

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:
[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px][COLOR=#353535][FONT=Arial][SIZE=17px]PP5V_S3 at [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]CD230 Pin 1 reads .401V in Diode Mode[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px][COLOR=#353535][FONT=Arial][SIZE=17px]PP5V_S3 at [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]C7300 Pin 1 reads .401V in Diode Mode[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

[FONT=Arial][SIZE=17px][COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px]So it looks like [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]PP5V_S3 is not shorted to Ground. (unless .401v is WAY off of what it should be?)[/SIZE][/FONT]

[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px]When checking voltage at C7300 Pin 1 with NO power applied it reads 0.000v.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px]When I apply power it goes to 0.002v.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:
I asked to check for short pulse(s) right after applying power. It may only pulse once and hard to catch on a multimeter.
Did you check power to RTC? R1800-1803?

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:
Ah, I wondered if it might be too fast to see on a DMM, you gotta be explicit with your instructions! :)

Will check all that and get back to you soon.

Thanks

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:
[COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px]C7300 Pin 1 (O’scope test) - maybe a 20mV pulse at 100mV/2s setting[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px] [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px]RTC Power C2810 Pin 1 - 0.366v[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px]RTC power C2811 Pin 1 - 0.401v

RTC - 32.89KHz signal present[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px] [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px]R1800-R1803 all have 3.398v on Pin 1 and between 3.1 and 3.3v on Pin 2[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px] [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
  [COLOR=#323333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=15px] [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: Who cares about power to the ODD? There must be corrosion somewhere else....

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:
I'm confused, did I do or say something to provoke attitude from you?

You asked me about PP5V_S3 and I found corrosion on a component that is connected to PP5V_S3 via a single resistor. No matter what subsection of the board that drives, isn't it worth my asking about it simply because it's connected to the signal you asked about?????

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message:
I assume you are intelligent enough to figure out that power to the ODD is not critical for the board to function.
Look better for corrosion somewhere.

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: Like I said, you asked about a signal that is one resistor away from a corroded component that I found. My question was legit. Your refusal to admit that and then offer a constructive way for me to move forward is disappointing, especially on a paid forum. No worries, my subscription is up in a few days and I've already cancelled the auto-renewal. Thanks for the help.

title: 820-2850 - ppbus_g3h 0.195v
message: That pretty fucking emo bro? It seems to me as a 3rd party viewer... he's actually trying to help you. I might be crazy but i pay for these forums because shit dude Louis puts out a shit ton of free information on you tube which basically lets you skip 200+ hours of research and we get to respectfully ask questions here about those videos. Sure we can comment on you tube but i want louis to keep putting shit like that out there so i see this as a way to support all the instructors and admins who help us with real world shit everyday.!
